snippet: The writer lobbied his parents for a chance to play tackle football when he turned 8, but, he says, because it worked out well for him does not mean it will work out well for everyone.
abstract: Scott Fujita essay explores his conflicted feelings, as former NFL linebacker, about children's  football programs, saying that he would have deep reservations about letting his children play despite sport's importance in his own life; describes mounting anxiety he felt during his professional career as he watched colleagues succumb to concussion-related brain diseases.
lead_paragraph: The writer lobbied his parents for a chance to play tackle football when he turned 8, but, he says, because it worked out well for him does not mean it will work out well for everyone.

headline.main: Would I Let My Son Play Football?
